Repurchase rate 1. % of customers who repurchased. = Count of customers who have placed more than 1 order within the given timeframe (e.g. 30 days), divided by cohort size
Repurchase rate 2. = Sum of orders placed by a cohort within a given timeframe (excluding their first orders) divided by cohort size
Cost to income ratio. = Total marketing costs in a period, divided by total sales in that period
Customer acquisition cost. = Total marketing costs in a period, divided by count of NC in that period

Sales per visit. = Total sales divided by count of total visits
Conversion rate. = Total count of orders divided by count of total visits
Unable to fulfil. Where the item ordered by a customer actually cannot be shipped out (e.g. not in stock)

Sell-through is a percentage of units sold during a period (usually 1 month but at THE ICONIC normally one week). It is calculated by dividing the number of units sold by the beginning on-hand inventory (for that same time period).

Average Order Value = Average order value (AOV) tracks the average dollar amount spent each time a customer places an order on a website or mobile app. To calculate your company’s average order value, simply divide total revenue by the number of orders.

OMS stands for Order Management System, which is a software platform used in eCommerce to manage and track orders from the time they are placed to the time they are delivered to the customer. An OMS is designed to streamline the order fulfillment process and ensure that orders are processed and shipped quickly and accurately.

Some of the key features of an OMS include:

Order processing: An OMS can automate the process of receiving and processing orders from multiple channels, including online marketplaces, websites, and brick-and-mortar stores.

Inventory management: An OMS can help manage inventory levels and provide real-time visibility into stock levels across multiple sales channels.

Shipping and tracking: An OMS can automate the shipping process and provide tracking information for each order, which can improve customer satisfaction.

Returns management: An OMS can streamline the process of processing returns and exchanges, including issuing refunds and restocking returned products.

Reporting and analytics: An OMS can provide detailed reports and analytics on order and inventory data, which can help eCommerce businesses make informed decisions about inventory levels, sales channels, and more.

Overall, an OMS is an essential tool for eCommerce businesses that want to streamline their order management process, improve efficiency, and provide a better customer experience.

WMS stands for Warehouse Management System, which is a software platform used in eCommerce to manage and track inventory and warehouse operations. A WMS is designed to help eCommerce businesses optimize their warehouse operations, improve inventory accuracy, and increase productivity.

Some of the key features of a WMS include:

Inventory management: A WMS can track inventory levels in real-time, including receiving, put-away, picking, and shipping of products.

Order fulfillment: A WMS can manage and prioritize the order picking process to ensure that orders are fulfilled accurately and on time.

Barcode scanning and labeling: A WMS can use barcode scanning and labeling to ensure accurate inventory counts and reduce errors in the picking and shipping processes.

Automation: A WMS can automate many warehouse processes, including inventory tracking, order picking, and shipping, which can improve efficiency and reduce labor costs.

Reporting and analytics: A WMS can provide detailed reports and analytics on warehouse operations, which can help eCommerce businesses make informed decisions about inventory levels, order fulfillment, and more.

Overall, a WMS is an essential tool for eCommerce businesses that want to optimize their warehouse operations, improve accuracy, and increase productivity. By using a WMS, eCommerce businesses can manage their inventory and warehouse operations more efficiently, reduce errors, and provide a better customer experience.

Wholesale is divided into 2 parts:

-Private Label: which are the brands we manufacture ourselves (i.e Atmos&Here)

-Branded: Brands that we own (ships from our warehouse, but we don’t own (i.e La Coste.. )

Both are owned by the iconic and ships from our warehouse

Branded is further broken into 2 parts - Consignment and Wholesale - Wholesale is technically when we buy the stock completely for the cost price and own it completely, so any profit or loss we make on it is ours.  Consignment is when we get the stock with promise of paying once we sell them, so if the stock doesn't sell through, we are entitled to return it back to the supplier and so won't be making a loss on stuff not sold.
Items not owned by us, and don’t ship from our warehouse, but we sell them on the website.

Total Net Merchandise Value (Total NMV) is defined as the value of goods (within both retail and marketplace segment) sold after actual and provisioned returns and rejections. Net of VAT.
Retail Net Merchandise Value (Retail NMV) is defined as the value of goods sold after actual and provisioned returns and rejections. Net of VAT.
Marketplace Net Merchandise Value (Marketplace NMV) is defined as the value of goods sold after actual and provisioned returns and rejections. Net of VAT.

Total original price value of retail goods sold after actual and provisioned cancellations relating to the period and before adjustments for discounts/coupons/markdowns and actual and provisioned rejections/returns. Net of VAT. (Total, retail, marketplace)

Market Size Definition:
All data to be net of tax and based on price paid, i.e. post discounts/ coupons. Offline + online retail market of apparel, footwear, beauty & personal care as well as beauty accessories Excluding black-market sales (i.e. untaxed, generated within informal retailing) and duty free sales (travel retail) Antique and/ or vintage clothing and footwear is also excluded Beauty & Personal care is the aggregation of baby and child-specific products, bath & shower, deodorants, hair care, colour cosmetics, men's grooming, oral hygiene, fragrances, skin care, depilatories, sun care and sets/kits. This is the aggregation of premium colour cosmetics, fragrances, deodorants, skin care, sun care, baby and child-specific products, bath and shower and hair care If you are using a different definition compared to the above, please do reach out pro-actively to discuss and make it transparent. Market Size to be shown in EUR'm.

Market Share (%) Definition:

Market share (%) = Total NMV (G1) / Market Size
Important to ensure that same underlying exchange rates are used for Total NMV (G1) and Market Size
Number of new customers who have purchased at least one item after cancellations, returns and rejections (“net purchase”) in the period.
Number of customers who made at least one net purchase in the period and who also made a net purchase within the last 12 months prior to the month of the first net purchase in the current period.

Number of customers who made at least one net purchase in the period and whose last net purchase was recorded more than 12 months ago prior to the month of the first net purchase in the current period.
Number of customers who have not made a net purchase in the period and whose last net purchase was recorded more than 12 months ago at the end of the period.
Total number of customers who made at least one net purchase in the last twelve months at the end of the period.
Rejected & Returned Orders / Orders before rejections and returns

Total NMV generated in the specified period by Existing & Reactivated Customer Cohorts
Total Net Orders generated in the specified Period by New Customer Cohort of the specified Period

definition: Total Net Orders generated in the specified Period by Existing Customer Cohorts
Total Net Items generated in the specified Period by New Customer Cohort of the specified Period

word: Net Items / Existing & Reactivated Customer Cohorts
definition: Total Net Items generated in the specified Period by Existing Customer Cohorts

Net Merchandise Value before Rejects/ Returns (NMV bRR) is defined as the value of goods sold before actual and provisioned returns and rejections. Net of VAT (total, retail or marketplace)
Retail Net Merchandise Value before Rejects/ Returns (Retail NMV bRR) is defined as the value of goods sold before actual and provisioned returns and rejections. Net of VAT.

Total Items sold after actual and provisioned returns and rejections (total items sold = Total net items, retail items sold - Net items - Retail, marketplace items sold - Net items - Marketplace)

Discounts - Temporary value off of current permanent price
Markdowns - Reduction of the original price to a new lower permanent price
Coupons - Value off at checkout not related to specific product
Discounts & Coupons & Markdowns / NMV bRR
Amount with no defined season OR continuity inventory
Amount attributable to all prior seasons

(Retail price (Initial Price of goods sold) - Cost price of goods sold - Inbound expenses (duties, transport etc) of goods sold) / Retail price( Initial Price of goods sold).
Retail Price ( Initial Price) = first black price with which the SKU is listed on the website before any discounts, markdowns, coupons are applied.
Agreed co-investment in marketing between two parties (brand and the platform), related to stock suppliers. Measured as % of NMV.
Total commission and fees made from goods sold after actual cancellations in marketplace, after rejections and returns but before discounts and markdowns

Funded Discounts (EUR) = Discounts (EUR) paid for by GFG (or regional business) to the marketplace seller.
Funded Discounts % = Funded Discounts (EUR) / (NMV bRR and before Funded Discounts (EUR)) * Gross Commission %
Net Commission % = Gross Commission % - Funded Discounts %
(Marketplace deliveries/parcels fulfilled by GFG) / (total marketplace deliveries/parcels)
Marketplace Fulfilment expenses / marketplace NMV
Net Commission % - Fulfilment expenses %

Describes % of total purchasing budget sold to customers at a specific point in time.
Sell Through % = COGS (up to the period end)/ COGS Buy In.
COGS Buy In = Wholesale cost of inventory received plus inventory committed, including inbound expenses (duties, transport etc.)
Product Margin % = (Landed Margin less Discounts & Coupons & Markdowns plus Co-marketing Income) / Retail Price/ Initial Price. Based on actual and provisioned rejects & returns.
Ratio showing how many times a company has sold and replaced inventory during a period, before rejections and returns.
Ratio showing how many times a company has sold and replaced inventory during a period, after rejections and returns.
Slow moving / residual stock sold to wholesalers
Average Inventory of the period / Cost of sales of the period * days in the period
Number of sellers who listed at least one item online in the last twelve months.
Number of new sellers who have listed at least one item online in the period
Number of sellers who have listed at least one item online and who also listed at least one item online within the last 12 months prior to the month of the first net purchase in the current period.
Number of Sellers who have not listed an item online in the period and whose last listing was recorded more than 12 months ago at the end of the period..
Number of sellers who listed at least one item online, who previously listed at least one item online prior to the last 12 months.

Number of customers who made at least one net purchase in the period and whose last net purchase was recorded more than 12 months ago prior to the month of the first net purchase in the current period.
New Sellers % = (New Sellers) / (Total Sellers). Total sellers = (New Sellers + Existing Sellers + Reactivated Sellers).
Churned Sellers % = Churned Sellers in the period / Active Sellers at the beginning of the period.
Reactivated Sellers % = (Reactivated Sellers) / (Total Sellers). Total Sellers = (New Sellers + Existing Sellers + Reactivated Sellers).
Average number of items available for sale in the specified period (retail, marketplace, total)
Actual and provisioned rejections and returns / NMV bRR. NMV bRR is defined in G.30
Rejection/Return Rate, % - Marketplace minus Rejection/Return Rate, % - Retail
(Marketplace deliveries/parcels fulfilled by partner) / (total marketplace deliveries/parcels)
